questions.text: According to IADPSG, the cut-off of fasting blood glucose for GDM is?
questions.solution: According IADPSG, cutoff for fasting blood glucose is 92 mg/dl.

choices.text: 2 doses of 6 mg 12 hours apart
4 doses of 6 mg 12 hours apart
2 doses of 12 mg 24 hours apart RROW
2 doses of 12 mg 12 hours apart

questions.text: Dose of dexamethasone given for fetal lung maturity?
questions.solution:
Steroid therapy in preterm labour:

  • Steroids are recommended for all women in preterm labour before 32 weeks with or without membrane ruptures in whom there is no evidence of According to ACOG, single dose steroid injection is recommended between 24 to 32 weeks. There is no consensus regarding treatment between 32-34 weeks. Corticosteroid therapy is not recommended before 24 weeks.

Advantage:

  • Steroids reduce the rate of respiratory distress syndrome, intraventricular hemorrhage and necrotising enterocolitis in the newborn.
  • The effect of treatment is maximal between 24 hours of the first dose and uptil 7
  • Earlier it was recommended to give repeated doses weekly till the patient delivers but this practice is associated with significant fetal and neonatal side effects like cerebral palsy and should be abandoned.
  • Betamethasone is the steroid of choice as it also prevents periventricular leukomalacia although dexamethasone can also be
  • Dose:
    1. Betamethasone = 2 doses of 12 mg, 24 hours apart,
    2. Dexamethasone: 4 doses of 6 mg, 12 hours

choices.text: Manual perineal support and maintain the head in deflexion and deliver
Delivery should be conducted in the lithotomy position

questions.text: Which of the following is a recommendation of WHO in the management of the second stage of labor?
questions.solution:
Warm compress to the perineum is recommended in the management of second stage of labour

Option A: Head should be maintained in flexion with controlled delivery of head.

Option D: Delivery can be conducted in any position

WHO latest guidelines

  • Delivery facilities must offer every woman privacy and allow her to be accompanied by her choice of a supportive person(husband, friend, mother, relative, TBA); all women must be treated with respect.
  • Psychosocial support, education, communication, choice of position, and pharmacological methods appropriately used during the first stage are all useful in relieving pain and distress in the second stage of labor.
  • There should be at least 2 people assisting at every birth, whether it is another health professional, family member, TBA, or village health worker. Arrangements for having another person besides the primary skilled attendant should be planned during the pregnancy.
  • Monitoring of the fetal heart beat must be continued during the second stage to allow early detection of bradycardia.
  • Routine episiotomy is harmful and should not be practiced.(Option C ruled out)
  • Women should not be forced or encouraged to push until they feel an urge to push.
  • Health facilities and skilled attendants should be provided with handheld battery powered or hand-cranked Dopplers for fetal heart auscultation after every contraction. These should be added to lists of essential commodities.
  • Local anesthetic should always be given for any episiotomy, episiotomy/laceration repair or forceps delivery.
  • Provision of critical skills for second stage management needs to be supported by policies as well as training, simulations(drills) and linkage with a functioning referral system.
  • Lack of access to instrumental delivery is a major deficit in obstetric care in many facilities; skills necessary for safe instrumental delivery must be emphasized in preservice and in-service education for all skilled attendants.

questions.text: A primigravida is in labor. Station -1, Cx posterior, 30% effaced, 1 cm dilatation, consistency - Soft. Calculate the bishop score?
questions.solution:
Station -1: 2

Cervix posterior: 0

30% effaced: 0

1 cm dilatation: 1

Consistency soft: 2

Total score: 5

Currently, effacement of cervix has been replaced by cervical length.

questions.text: Double bleb sign in USG indicates
questions.solution: The earliest evidence of an embryo is seen about 2 weeks later, when two small bubbles(amniotic and yolk sacs) attach to the wall of the gestational sac.The embryonic disc is located between the two bubbles. This is called the double-bleb sign.

questions.text: A 10-week primigravida presents with bleeding PV. On examination, the uterus corresponds to 12 weeks. TVS was done and it is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Hydatidiform mole is a benign neoplasm of chorion with malignant potential.
  • It is the most common form of gestational trophoblastic disease.
  • It is an abnormal condition of the placenta where there are partly degenerative and partly proliferative changes in the young chorionic villi.
  • Grossly:It is characterised by multiple grape like vesicles filling and distending the uterus, usually in absence of an intact The vesicles are filled with interstitial fluid similar to ascitic or oedema fluid but is rich in hCG.
  • Microscopically it is characterised by:
    • Marked proliferation of the syncytial and cytotrophoblastic
    • Thinning of the stromal tissue due to hydropic degeneration(edema of villous stroma).
    • Avascular
  • Radiologically: On USG, snowstorm appearance seen

Risk factors

  • Risk is more in women too elderly(> 35) or too younger(< 18 years).
  • Low socioeconomic
  • Historyof molar
  • Dietdeficient in protein, folic acid and vitamin
  • Blood group Awomen married to group O men.

Note: Maternal age > 35 years and dietary deficiencies are risk factors for complete mole whereas partial mole is linked to the use of oral contraceptive pills and history of irregular menstruation.

Familial repetitive hydatidiform mole has been linked to a missense mutation in the NLRP7 locus on chromosome 19;

Sonography (shown above) displays the "snowstorm" appearance, which is characteristic of molar pregnancy. Classically, a 'snowstorm pattern' results from the presence of a complex vesicular intrauterine mass containing many 'grape-like' cysts.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old girl presented with irregular cycles and weight gain. The neck of the patient shows the given finding as given in the image. On USG, Ovaries were found to have an increased volume. which of the following in treatment?

1.Lap ovarian drilling.
2. Spironolactone
3. Lifestyle modifications
4. COC
questions.solution:
The image shows acanthosis nigricans and the other symptoms mentioned in the question are suggestive of PCOD.

Depends on the complain of the patient

Clomifene is one of several alternatives for ovulation induction in those who are infertile due to anovulation or oligoovulation. Evidence is lacking for the use of clomifene in those who are infertile without a known reason In such cases, studies have observed a clinical pregnancy rate 5.6% per cycle with clomifene treatment vs. 1.3%-4.2% per cycle without treatment.

Clomiphene citrate causes MULTIFOLLICULAR DEVELOPMENT in contrast to Letrozole which leads to monofollicular development. Hence Letrozole is the current drug of choice for follicle stimulation in case of PCOS.

Proper timing of the drug is important; it should be taken starting on about the fifth day of the cycle and there should be frequent intercourse.

The following procedures may be used to monitor induced cycles:

  • Follicular monitoring with vaginal ultrasound, starting 4-6 days after the last pill. Serial transvaginal ultrasound can reveal the size and number of developing follicles. It can also provide presumptive evidence of ovulation such as the sudden collapse of the preovulatory follicle and an increase in fluid volume in the rectouterine pouch. After ovulation, it may reveal signs of luteinization such as loss of clearly defined follicular margins and appearance of internal echoes.
  • Serum estradiol levels, starting 4-6 days after the last pill
  • Adequacy of LH surge by urine LH surge tests 3 to 4 days after last clomifene pill
  • Post-coital test 1-3 days before ovulation to check whether there are at least 5 progressive sperm per HPF
  • Mid-luteal progesterone, with at least 10ng/ml 7-9 days after ovulation being regarded as adequate.

questions.text: All of the following are the long-acting reversible contraceptive methods, except?

A couple presents to the infertility clinic with normal HSG and a semen analysis report with azoospermia. Which of the following test is useful to differentiate between testicular cause and obstructive vas deferens
questions.solution:
• In testicular cause there is decreased or no production of testicular hormones which in turn have negative feedback on FSH.
  • In obstructive vas deferens the FSH levels are normal as the testicular hormone production is not affected.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with a no history of DM and HTN came with post-menopausal bleeding. Which of the following you will do to evaluate the cause?
questions.solution:
Postmenopausal bleeding is vaginal bleeding that occurs a year or more after your last menstrual period. It can be a symptom of vaginal dryness, polyps(noncancerous growths) or other changes in your reproductive system. In about 10% of women, bleeding after menopause is a sign of uterine cancer.

The most common causes are: inflammation and thinning of the vaginal lining (atrophic vaginitis) or womb lining(endometrial atrophy) caused by lower oestrogen levels. cervical or womb polyps - growths that are usually non-cancerous.

For any patient above 45 years it is necessary to perform endometrial biopsy to rule out endometrial cancer.

Options B,C,D are methods for screening and diagnosis of cervical Ca.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl was brought by her mother to the outpatient department with complaints of primary amenorrhea. With normal breast development and pubic hair. On examination, the blind-ending vagina and uterus were not able to palpate. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mullerian agenesis or Mayer-Rokintansky-Kuster-hauser syndrome is a congenital malformation characterized by a failure of the Mullerian ducts to develop, resulting in absent uterus and variable malformations of the vagina, while both ovaries are intact and functioning.

Ovaries are present and function normally so secondary sexual characteristics are normal. External genitalia are also normal as testosterone is absent.

Patients with müllerian agenesis typically present in late adolescence or as young adults, well after menarche was expected, with primary amenorrhea as their only complaint. They exhibit normal, symmetrical breast and pubic hair development, have no visible vagina, and have no symptoms or signs of cryptomenorrhea because the rudimentary uteri contain no functional endometrium.

Here's a comparison of Gonadal Dysgenesis in Turner Syndrome, Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS), and Müllerian Agenesis:

  • Karyotype:
    • Turner Syndrome: 45, X (most common).
    • AIS: 46, XY (can be complete or partial AIS).
    • Müllerian Agenesis: 46, XX.
  • Primary Cause:
    • Turner Syndrome: Caused by the absence of one X chromosome, which affects gonadal development.
    • AIS: Due to a mutation in the androgen receptor gene, leading to insensitivity to androgens.
    • Müllerian Agenesis: A congenital absence of Müllerian ducts, which usually form the uterus and upper vagina.
  • Gonadal Development:
    • Turner Syndrome: Leads to streak gonads, which are underdeveloped and nonfunctional ovaries.
    • AIS: Develops testes that are often undescended (depending on the type of AIS).
    • Müllerian Agenesis: Ovaries develop normally.
  • External Genitalia:
    • Turner Syndrome: Female, but with underdeveloped secondary sex characteristics.
    • AIS: Appears female in complete AIS, while partial AIS can present with ambiguous genitalia.
    • Müllerian Agenesis: Female external genitalia.
  • Internal Reproductive Structures:
    • Turner Syndrome: Uterus and fallopian tubes are typically absent or underdeveloped.
    • AIS: Complete AIS results in no uterus or fallopian tubes; partial AIS may retain some structures.
    • Müllerian Agenesis: The uterus and upper two-thirds of the vagina are absent, though ovaries are normal.
  • Secondary Sexual Characteristics:
    • Turner Syndrome: Delayed or absent puberty and limited breast development.
    • AIS: Normal breast development occurs due to estrogen production from testosterone.
    • Müllerian Agenesis: Normal breast development.
  • Hormone Levels:
    • Turner Syndrome: High levels of FSH and LH due to lack of feedback from the underdeveloped gonads.
    • AIS: High testosterone, which converts to estrogen; this results in normal breast development in complete AIS.
    • Müllerian Agenesis: Normal hormone levels.
  • Menstruation:
    • Turner Syndrome: Primary amenorrhea (absence of menstruation).
    • AIS: Primary amenorrhea.
    • Müllerian Agenesis: Primary amenorrhea.
  • Fertility:
    • Turner Syndrome: Infertile due to gonadal dysgenesis.
    • AIS: Infertile because of the absence of the uterus.
    • Müllerian Agenesis: Infertile due to the absence of the uterus.
  • Associated Features:
    • Turner Syndrome: Short stature, webbed neck, and possible cardiovascular anomalies, such as coarctation of the aorta.
    • AIS: Often tall, with sparse or absent body hair in complete AIS.
    • Müllerian Agenesis: Typically normal stature, and the presence of a blind vaginal pouch.
  • Treatment:
    • Turner Syndrome: Growth hormone and estrogen replacement therapy to address short stature and delayed puberty.
    • AIS: Psychological support and possible hormone therapy for partial AIS.
    • Müllerian Agenesis: Vaginal dilators or surgical creation of a neovagina to enable sexual function.

A female presented with frothy vaginal discharge and itching. On examination, she was found to have a strawberry cervix. Which of the following is the drug of choice?
questions.solution: These features are suggestive of Trichomoniasis and the drug of choice is Metronidazole.

questions.text: A 24 year old female with complain of discharge and pruritis. A Pap smear image of the discharge is given - diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The HPE image is suggestive of clue cells.

Bacterial vaginosis is caused by Gardnerella vaginalis. It is diagnosed using Amsel's criteria. Presence of clue cells is one of the criterion. Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells with granular, stippled appearance due to the attachment of bacteria.

questions.text: Which of the following is a formulation of emergency contraceptive used in INDIA?
questions.solution:
It can be started up to five days(120 hours) after unprotected intercourse but greatest protection occurs if it is given within 72 hours of unprotected sex. Emergency contraception is also known as emergency birth control, backup birth control and the morning after pill.

Method of choice/M/C method used = Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg single dose(Tablet = 0.75 mg 2 tablets together)

Note: The overall risk of having pregnancy after single unprotected intercourse is 8%.

Mechanism of Action

  • Delay ovulation-Hormonal methods
  • Spermicidal-Nonhormonal methods
  • Prevents implantation by affecting endometrial
  • M/C side effect: Nausea, vomiting
  • There are No C/I for emergency

Note: E-pills are available free of cost by Govt. of India. It has Levonorgest.

One new pill available world wide but not in India is Ella - 30 mg of ulipristal.

Indications

  • Breakage or slipping of condom
  • Forgot to take OC pills or insert diaphragm or sponge
  • Diaphragm slipped out of place
  • Miscalculated "safe" days
  • Failure to practice coitus interruptus
  • Not using any birth control method
  • Forced to have unprotected vaginal sex,
